reading_list.title: The neural basis of mental imagery
reading_list.notes: Foundational 1989 paper on visual mental imagery. Discusses whether images are different from verbal thoughts, share mechanisms with visual perception, and use spatial representation. Shows imagery involves prestriate occipital cortex, parietal and temporal cortex.

citations_formatted.chicago: MJ Farah. "The neural basis of mental imagery." 1989.

reading_list.title: Capacity for visual features in mental rotation
reading_list.notes: Shows strikingly low capacity for mental rotation: only one feature can remain attached to one part. Features remain "glued" via singular focus of attention (typically on object top). Argues human visual system not suited for keeping multiple features attached during mental rotation. Important for understanding mental rotation mechanisms and science education.

reading_list.title: Quantifying aphantasia through drawing: Those without visual imagery show deficits in object but not spatial memory
reading_list.authors: WA Bainbridge, Z Pounder, AF Eardley, CI Baker
reading_list.notes: Large-scale study showing people with aphantasia have deficits in object memory but INTACT spatial memory. Used drawing tasks scored by 2,795 raters. Aphantasic participants recalled fewer objects, less color, more verbal scaffolding, BUT equivalent spatial accuracy and fewer errors. Provides evidence for separate memory systems for object vs spatial information. Important experimental validation of aphantasia.

reading_list.title: Sensory representations in primary visual cortex are not sufficient for subjective imagery
reading_list.authors: G Cabbai, C Racey, J Simner, C Dance, J Ward, S Forster
reading_list.notes: Critical fMRI study showing V1 sensory representations can be DISSOCIATED from subjective imagery experience. Aphantasics showed V1 decoding during passive listening (no reported imagery) but not during voluntary imagery. Visualizers showed V1 decoding for both, with precuneus involvement. Demonstrates that V1 activity alone is not sufficient for conscious imagery - precuneus appears key for subjective experience. Major theoretical contribution to understanding neural basis of imagery.

reading_list.title: Comparing eye movements during position tracking and identity tracking: No evidence for separate systems
reading_list.notes: Eye movement study comparing position tracking (MOT) vs identity tracking (MIT) tasks. Found NO difference in eye movements between the two tasks when stimuli were identical. Challenges the idea of separate tracking systems. Shows observers can track either position or identity using the same eye-movement mechanisms. Important for understanding attention and tracking mechanisms, relevant for mental rotation eye-tracking studies.

reading_list.title: Visual mental imagery engages the left fusiform gyrus, but not the early visual cortex: A meta-analysis of neuroimaging evidence
reading_list.authors: A Spagna, D Hajhajate, J Liu, P Bartolomeo
reading_list.notes: Major meta-analysis of 46 fMRI studies challenging dominant neural model. Shows visual mental imagery engages LEFT FUSIFORM GYRUS and fronto-parietal networks, but NO EVIDENCE for early visual cortex (V1) activity. Reconciles neuroimaging with patient lesion data - occipital damage spares imagery but temporal lobe damage impairs it. Proposes revised model: fronto-parietal networks modulate a core temporal network centered on fusiform imagery node. Critical theoretical paper - directly relevant to Cabbai et al. 2024 findings on V1 dissociation.

reading_list.title: Attentional tracking takes place over perceived rather than veridical positions
reading_list.authors: MR Maechler, P Cavanagh, PU Tse
reading_list.notes: Shows attention operates on PERCEIVED positions rather than veridical (physical) positions. Used motion illusion where Gabors with moving internal texture appear shifted. Tracking performance better when objects APPEAR further apart, even if physically same distance. Critical for understanding how attention and mental rotation work on perceptual representations, not raw retinal input. Complements Wu & Wolfe on tracking mechanisms.

reading_list.title: Preserved recognition of basic visual features despite lack of awareness of shape: Evidence from a case of neglect
reading_list.authors: S Karakose-Akbiyik, TM Schubert, A Caramazza
reading_list.notes: Neuropsychological case study (patient DH with spatial neglect) showing DISSOCIATION between shape awareness and basic feature processing. DH lacks awareness of left-side shapes but has INTACT recognition of color, orientation, and location of those same regions. Cannot recognize objects/faces/words but CAN report colors within their boundaries. Demonstrates spatial attention is critical for shape integration but NOT for basic feature detection. Shows features can be processed without conscious shape awareness - major theoretical implication for feature binding and attention.

reading_list.title: Mental rotation of three-dimensional objects
reading_list.notes: THE seminal 1971 paper that launched mental rotation research. Showed reaction time is LINEAR function of angular difference between objects - suggesting analog mental rotation process. Found no difference between picture-plane vs depth rotations. Demonstrated mental rotation operates on 3D representations. Over 9,300 citations - one of most influential papers in cognitive psychology. Essential reference for ANY mental rotation research.

reading_list.title: Mechanical reasoning by mental simulation
reading_list.notes: Influential review on how people reason about mechanical systems through mental simulation. Argues for "piecemeal" animation model: people mentally animate components one-by-one rather than whole systems simultaneously. Shows individual differences in spatial ability predict mechanical reasoning. Discusses relationship between mental simulation, mental rotation, and external diagrams. Important for understanding spatial cognition in STEM contexts and science education. Connects mental rotation research to practical reasoning tasks.

reading_list.notes: Important theoretical paper on mental imagery by Pylyshyn

reading_list.notes: Classic paper on dissociation between perception and action systems

reading_list.title: The human imagination: the cognitive neuroscience of visual mental imagery
reading_list.notes: Major review on visual mental imagery covering aphantasia to hyperphantasia. Shows imagery involves frontal to sensory areas overlapping with DMN.

reading_list.title: Statistics of mental imagery
reading_list.notes: Foundational 1880 paper by Francis Galton introducing systematic study of individual differences in mental imagery. First to document that some people lack visual imagery (aphantasia precursor). Pioneered questionnaire-based assessment of imagery vividness. Highly influential in establishing mental imagery as legitimate area of scientific inquiry.

reading_list.title: Composite Portraits, Made by Combining Those of Many Different Persons Into a Single Resultant Figure
reading_list.notes: Galton's 1878 paper on composite photography - pioneering work on visual averaging and mental representation. Developed technique of combining multiple photographs into composite images. Foundational for understanding how the mind forms prototypes and averages visual information. Predates his mental imagery work and influenced theories of mental representation. Important for understanding mental rotation as manipulation of internal representations.

reading_list.title: Physics versus graphics as an organizing dichotomy in cognition
reading_list.notes: Major theoretical paper arguing intuitive mental simulation includes basic split between physical simulation and graphical rendering. Based on split in engineered systems (physics engines vs graphics rendering). Uses physics/graphics distinction to explain findings across domains including aphantasia, imagery, visual streams, and object tracking. Proposes natural division of labor in cognitive systems. Published in Trends in Cognitive Sciences 2025.

reading_list.title: The dissociation theory of Pierre Janet
reading_list.notes: Hilgard's 1957 review of Pierre Janet's dissociation theory. Janet (1889-1907) proposed that mental phenomena could become dissociated from conscious awareness. Foundational for understanding divided consciousness and psychological automaticity. Relevant to mental imagery and mental rotation as dissociable cognitive processes that can occur outside focal awareness. Historical importance for understanding modularity of mental processes.

reading_list.title: How Pierre Janet used pathological psychology to save the philosophical self
reading_list.notes: Historical analysis of Pierre Janet's 1889 doctoral dissertation L'Automatisme psychologique. Argues Janet bridged old spiritualistic psychology (claiming unity of self) with new psychology (questioning it). Shows Janet used pathological psychology to preserve philosophical concept of self while establishing scientific psychology. Important for understanding historical development of concepts like dissociation, automaticity, and modularity of mind that underpin modern theories of mental imagery and mental rotation.

reading_list.title: Frames of reference and mental imagery
reading_list.notes: Hinton & Parsons' 1981 chapter on frames of reference in mental imagery from Attention and Performance IX. Important contribution to understanding how spatial mental representations use different reference frames. Relevant to mental rotation as rotation involves transforming spatial representations across reference frames.

reading_list.title: Disambiguation of mental rotation by spatial frames of reference
reading_list.notes: Asakura & Inui 2011 paper showing spatial reference frames actively disambiguate object rotations when rotational axis is ambiguous. Demonstrates vertical environmental axis is preferentially used over object-intrinsic axis for efficient minimum rotation. When vertical axis absent, object-intrinsic axis resolves rotation ambiguity. Suggests reference frames are incorporated into internal model of object rotations within Bayesian framework for motion perception. Published in i-Perception.

reading_list.title: Mental imagery: In search of a theory
reading_list.notes: Pylyshyn's 2002 critique of picture theories of mental imagery, particularly Kosslyn's theory. Argues against the idea that mental images are depictive/spatial representations in a 'visual buffer' examined by a 'mind's eye'. Major contribution to the imagery debate, questioning whether neuroscience evidence supports picture theory. Challenges claims about spatial properties of images and cognitive impenetrability of imagery processes. Published in Behavioral and Brain Sciences with extensive peer commentary.

reading_list.title: Paradoxical thinking and change in the frames of reference
reading_list.notes: Westenholz 1993 paper on how paradoxical situations cause 'deframing' of mental frames of reference. Describes how employees experience paradoxical situations that render previous frames meaningless, forcing engagement with new, unknown levels of thinking. Shows how discovering that categories are socially constructed enables new ways of understanding environment. Relevant to mental rotation as it involves changing frames of reference and cognitive restructuring. Published in Organization Studies.

reading_list.title: Abstraction and concept formation: An interpretative investigation into a group of psychological frames of reference
reading_list.notes: Pikas 1966 book on abstraction and concept formation through lens of psychological frames of reference. Early comprehensive treatment of how frames of reference shape concept formation and abstraction processes. Historical importance for understanding theoretical foundations of reference frames in cognitive psychology. Relevant to mental rotation as abstract spatial transformations require concepts organized within reference frames. Published by De Gruyter.

reading_list.title: Knowledge across reference frames: Cognitive maps and image spaces
reading_list.notes: Bottini & Doeller 2020 review on how conceptual knowledge is organized according to spatial geometries across multiple reference frames. Distinguishes cognitive maps (hippocampal, world-centered) from image spaces (parietal, self-centered). Proposes hippocampal-parietal network accounting for organization and retrieval of knowledge across reference frames. Suggests both may be manifestations of mind's propensity to create low-dimensional internal models. Direct relevance to mental rotation as it involves transforming between reference frames. Published in Trends in Cognitive Sciences.

reading_list.title: Unraveling the cerebral dynamics of mental imagery
reading_list.authors: AJ Pegna, A Khateb, L Spinelli, M Seeck, T Landis, CM Michel
reading_list.notes: Pegna et al. 1997 ERP study using spatiotemporal analysis to elucidate topography and chronology of mental rotation. Found one time segment (400-600ms) that increased in duration with rotation angle, suggesting this is when mental rotation occurs. Inverse solution showed right-lateralized occipito-parietal activity. Important for understanding temporal dynamics and neural substrates of mental rotation beyond what static imaging can reveal. Published in Human Brain Mapping.

reading_list.title: Motor processes in mental rotation
reading_list.authors: M Wexler, SM Kosslyn, A Berthoz
reading_list.notes: Wexler, Kosslyn & Berthoz 1998 landmark study showing mental rotation relies on motor processes. Used dual-task paradigm where subjects performed mental rotation while executing unseen motor rotation. Found compatible motor rotation speeds mental rotation while incompatible directions interfere. Correlation between mental and motor rotation angles only when directions compatible. Motor rotation modifies inverted V-shaped RT function. Direct evidence that mental image transformations are guided by motor processes even for abstract objects. Published in Cognition.
